question:
In context of the Inter-state River Water Dispute (amendment) bill, 2019, passed in the Lok Sabha, consider the following statements:
  1. The bill, when enacted, would replace all existing tribunals with a single tribunal.
  2. A Dispute Resolution Committee would be approached before going to the tribunal level.
  3. A decision from tribunal level resolution is final and binding on the parties.
Select the correct option from the codes given below:
explanation: Explanation: Statement 1 is correct: Currently, the existing tribunals have shown low performance on the fronts of timely resolution and also the number of resolutions awarded. Only 4 out of the 9 tribunals have awarded decisions in cases. These took a long time, ranging from 7 to 28 years. The bill seeks to correct this by consolidating the tribunals into a single central body with multiple benches. The tribunal will operate on a time frame (disputes to be resolved in 2 years- extendable by a year). Statement 2 is correct: The bill will set up a Dispute Resolution Committee (DRC). The DRC will seek to amicably resolve the disputes between the states. It will be composed of a chairperson and an expert with at least 15 years’ experience. It will also have members from the disputing states. This process is to be completed in a year (extendable by 6 months). If this fails, the states will approach the tribunal. Statement 3 is correct: The tribunal will deliver its resolution within a time frame and this decision is binding on the parties. The order is equivalent to a Supreme Court order. The bill also mandates the central government to set up scheme in support of the tribunal’s decision.
